notesStmt.note: The final flyleaf is foliated as fol. 110
Texts by Erasmus, Prudentius, and Marco Girolamo Vida identified by Nicholas Herman, March 2017
De Ricci, Seymour, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York,: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2044, no. 110.

Free Library of Philadelphia, A Descriptive Catalogue of the John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts in the Free Library of Philadelphia, compiled by Edwin Wolf, 2nd , with an introduction by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach (Philadelphia: The Free Library, 1937), p. 193, no. 179.

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This Prayer Book, which contains prayers and other devotional texts by Erasmus, Prudentius, and Marco Girolamo Vida, can be dated to circa 1540. It is illustrated with forty-five copperplate engravings depicting the Life of Christ, which are integral to the book's structure. The support is paper.

msItem.title: Prudentius, Hymn for before meals ("Ante cibum hymnus")
msItem.incipit: O crucifer bone, lucisator Omnipotens pie...

msItem.title: Erasmus, Prayer of Thanksgiving for Victory
Erasmus, Prayer to Our Father, Our Father
Erasmus, Prayer to Our Father, Thy Kingdom Come
Erasmus, Prayer to Our Father, Thy Will be Done
Erasmus, Prayer to Our Father, Our Daily Bread
Erasmus, Prayer to Our Father, And Forgive Us
Erasmus, Prayer to Our Father, And Lead us Not into Temptation
Erasmus, Prayer to Our Father, But Deliver us from Evil
Erasmus, Prayer to God the Father
msItem.incipit: Indulgissime pater, qui summus in summis habitas...

msItem.title: Erasmus, Prayer to God the Son
Erasmus, Prayer to God the Holy Spirit
msItem.incipit: Adorande spiritus, qui triadem illam omnipotentem absolvis...

msItem.title: Erasmus, Prayer to Jesus Son of the Virgin
msItem.incipit: Adoro te prona supplicique mente generis instaurator humani...
msItem.explicit: ...semper adorandus cum patre et spiritu sancto. Amen.

support.watermark: Cropped watermark visible at top of fol. 6

supportDesc.extent: i+109+i; 138 x 96 mm bound to 146 x 101 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto; modern numbering of engravings in lower corner of relevant pages

layoutDesc.layout: One column of nineteen lines; parchment scraps with gothic script used as reinforcement visible at front (with musical notation, before fol. 1) and back (with text, after fol. 109); written area: 88 x 60 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Forty copperplate engravings depicting the Life of Christ, the first colored, the subsequent engravings occupying every other leaf
Front coverPanel, Christ triumphing over death
Inside front coverBookplate, Eberhard von Kniestedt
28rEngraving, Christ teaching the Elders in the Temple
43vEngraving, Christ Expelling the Money Changers from the Temple
45vEngraving, Judas receives thirty pieces of Silver
47rEngraving, Christ breaking bread with the Apostles (?)
Back coverPanel, Christ triumphing over death

binding.p: Contemporary German stamped calf, within a border of scrolls and medallions; on each side a stamped center panel gilt showing Christ triumphing over Death, with the initials HGV (attributed to Hans von Ghent), in cloth case

history.provenance: Owned by Joachim, Baron von Windhag, his bookplate of 1661 on verso of first flyleaf; Eberhard von Kniestedt, his bookplate on upper pastedown; Henry Huth (The Huth Library, V, 1880, p. 1718; A. H. Huth, A catalogue of the woodcuts and engravings in the Huth library, 1910, pp. 13-14); A. H. Huth sale of engravings, Sotheby's London, July 4, 1911, no. 47; to E. Parsons; (directly to?) John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936
